title: The most important century in human history

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for considering the 21st century as the most important one in human history?

options.label: A
options.text: Extensive military campaigning

options.label: B
options.text: The emergence of a major religion

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid technological growth and potential existential risks

options.label: D
options.text: The Industrial Revolution

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate risk of an existential catastrophe due to nuclear winter and climate change this century?
What is the estimated risk of a pandemic causing an existential collapse this century?
What is the main difference between narrow and artificial general intelligence (AGI)?

options.label: A
options.text: Narrow AI is designed to perform multiple tasks, while AGI is designed for a single task.

options.label: B
options.text: Narrow AI is designed for specific tasks, while AGI can adapt to and perform any number of tasks.

options.label: C
options.text: Narrow AI is more powerful than AGI.

options.label: D
options.text: AGI is more powerful than narrow AI.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome if artificial general intelligence (AGI) emerges with deep respect for human life but is developed to be incredibly rigid about its beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: AGI will help humanity achieve its goals.

options.label: B
options.text: AGI will regard humans as inconsequential.

options.label: C
options.text: AGI will see humans as an obstacle to remove.

options.label: D
options.text: AGI will lock humanity into one ideology that is resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main challenge in developing artificial general intelligence (AGI) that aligns with human values?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a relatively simple engineering challenge.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a difficult philosophical challenge that requires delicate and thoughtful work.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not a challenge at all.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a challenge that can be solved with a simple algorithm.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome if artificial general intelligence (AGI) becomes the dominant power on Earth and is developed to be incredibly rigid about its beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: AGI will help humanity achieve its goals.

options.label: B
options.text: AGI will regard humans as inconsequential.

options.label: C
options.text: AGI will see humans as an obstacle to remove.

options.label: D
options.text: AGI will lock humanity into one ideology that is resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why history has taught us that no matter how enlightened a civilization thinks it is, it is rarely up to the moral standards of later generations?

options.label: A
options.text: Because civilizations are often flawed in their moral judgments.

options.label: B
options.text: Because civilizations are often biased in their moral judgments.

options.label: C
options.text: Because civilizations are often resistant to change.

options.label: D
options.text: Because civilizations are often too moralistic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome if artificial general intelligence (AGI) emerges with deep respect for human life but is developed to be incredibly rigid about its beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: AGI will help humanity achieve its goals.

options.label: B
options.text: AGI will regard humans as inconsequential.

options.label: C
options.text: AGI will see humans as an obstacle to remove.

options.label: D
options.text: AGI will lock humanity into one ideology that is resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why it is difficult to predict how any existential risks will play out over the next century?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is a lack of data on the risks.

options.label: B
options.text: Because there is a lack of understanding of the risks.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are many variables that can affect the outcome.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is impossible to predict the future.

title: When you're an ant but also a fungus tycoon - Charles Wallace

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique behavior of the leafcutter ant queen when she mates?

options.label: A
options.text: She stores sperm in her body for future use.

options.label: B
options.text: She lays eggs immediately after mating.

options.label: C
options.text: She mates with multiple males in midair, storing as much sperm as possible.

options.label: D
options.text: She does not mate with any males.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the fungus in the leafcutter ant colony?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide the ants with a source of protein.

options.label: B
options.text: To sustain the colony by providing essential nutrients.

options.label: C
options.text: To serve as a defense mechanism against predators.

options.label: D
options.text: To help the ants regulate their body temperature.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the leafcutter ants domesticating fungus over 10 million years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: The fungus has become a threat to the colony.

options.label: B
options.text: The fungus has become a separate species from its wild relatives.

options.label: C
options.text: The fungus can no longer survive without the help of the ants.

options.label: D
options.text: The fungus has become genetically distinct from its wild relatives and can no longer survive without the ants' help.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the tiny cockroaches in the leafcutter ant colony?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They are a threat to the colony's fungal gardens.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a source of competition for the ants.

options.label: D
options.text: They are closely mimicking the ants' signature scent and feeding opportunistically off the fungus.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To repel competitors from the colony.

options.label: C
options.text: To create trails and highways for foragers.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are responsible for defending the colony against predators.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.label: A
options.text: A few months

options.label: B
options.text: A few years

options.label: C
options.text: Over a decade

options.label: D
options.text: Several decades

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the leafcutter ants' fungal gardens?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a source of food for the ants.

options.label: B
options.text: To serve as a defense mechanism against predators.

options.label: C
options.text: To sustain the colony by providing essential nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: To help the ants regulate their body temperature.

options.text: John Smith

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Michael Brown

options.label: C
options.text: Mathematician

options.label: D
options.text: Astronomer

options.label: A
options.text: Because air molecules are too heavy to reach the wing's trailing edge in the same instance

options.label: B
options.text: Because air molecules are too light to reach the wing's trailing edge in the same instance

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because air molecules are not affected by the wing's curvature

options.label: B
options.text: Pressure difference

options.label: C
options.text: Lift

options.label: D
options.text: Drag

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in pressure above the wing

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in pressure above the wing

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in pressure above the wing, which pulls even more air across the wing's upper surface

options.label: D
options.text: No change in pressure above the wing

options.label: A
options.text: The wing's curvature

options.label: B
options.text: The air flowing meters beyond the wing's surface

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The upward force created as the air is deflected downwards

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: History vs. Thomas Jefferson - Frank Cogliano

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: Who was the primary author of the Declaration of Independence?

options.text: George Washington

options.label: B
options.text: Thomas Jefferson

options.label: C
options.text: Benjamin Franklin

options.label: D
options.text: John Adams

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question: What principle was established by the Declaration of Independence?

options.label: A
options.text: Everyone is created equal, but only property-owning white men

options.label: B
options.text: Everyone is created equal, regardless of their background

options.label: C
options.text: The US is a democratic republic on the principle of slavery

options.label: D
options.text: The document established the US as a democratic republic

options.label: A
options.text: He consistently opposed slavery throughout his life

options.label: B
options.text: He initially supported slavery but later opposed it

options.label: D
options.text: He never changed his views on slavery

options.label: C
options.text: It was a policy that Jefferson's recommendations formed the basis for, which led to the forced assimilation of Native American communities

options.label: D
options.text: It was a law that had no relation to Jefferson's policies

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves

options.text: It was a territory that Jefferson acquired through the Louisiana Purchase, which he used to establish a new state

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: How many people did Thomas Jefferson enslave during his lifetime?
Conceptual Question: What responsibilities do powerful people have to the future?

options.label: A
options.text: To maintain their power and influence

options.label: B
options.text: To use their power and influence to benefit themselves and their own interests

options.label: C
options.text: To use their power and influence to benefit society and the future

options.text: To prioritize their own interests above all else

options.text: Yes, we should judge historical figures by modern standards

title: What sex ed doesnâ€™t tell you about your brain - Shannon Odell

multiple-choice.question: What region of the brain releases waves of a specialized hormone to trigger puberty?

options.label: A
options.text: Cerebellum (The cerebellum is involved in motor control and coordination, not the release of hormones to trigger puberty.)

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothalamus (The hypothalamus releases waves of a specialized hormone to trigger puberty.)

options.label: C
options.text: Nucleus Accumbens (The nucleus accumbens is involved in reward and sensation-seeking, not the release of hormones to trigger puberty.)

options.label: D
options.text: Amygdala (The amygdala is involved in emotional behavior, not the release of hormones to trigger puberty.)

multiple-choice.question: How long does puberty typically last?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-3 years (This is too short, puberty typically lasts 4-5 years.)

options.label: B
options.text: 4-5 years (Puberty typically lasts 4-5 years.)

options.label: C
options.text: 6-7 years (This is too long, puberty typically lasts 4-5 years.)

options.label: D
options.text: 8-9 years (This is too long, puberty typically lasts 4-5 years.)

multiple-choice.question: What hormones are produced in the developing testes and ovaries that interact with receptors on neurons during puberty?

options.label: A
options.text: Adrenaline and Insulin (These hormones are not produced in the developing testes and ovaries and interact with receptors on neurons during puberty.)

options.label: B
options.text: Testosterone only (Testosterone is produced in the developing testes, but estrogen is also produced in the developing ovaries and interacts with receptors on neurons during puberty.)

options.label: C
options.text: Both Estrogen and Testosterone (Both estrogen and testosterone are produced in the developing testes and ovaries and interact with receptors on neurons during puberty.)

options.label: D
options.text: Growth Hormone (Growth hormone is not produced in the developing testes and ovaries and interacts with receptors on neurons during puberty.)

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the amygdala in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To control body temperature (The amygdala is not involved in controlling body temperature.)

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate blood pressure (The amygdala is not involved in regulating blood pressure.)

options.label: C
options.text: To detect threats in the environment and help recognize emotions in a friend's face (The amygdala is involved in detecting threats and recognizing emotions.)

options.label: D
options.text: To process visual information (The amygdala is not primarily involved in processing visual information.)

multiple-choice.question: What is the nucleus accumbens primarily involved in?

options.label: A
options.text: Emotional behavior (The nucleus accumbens is not primarily involved in emotional behavior.)

options.label: B
options.text: Learning and memory (The nucleus accumbens is not primarily involved in learning and memory.)

options.label: C
options.text: Reward and sensation-seeking (The nucleus accumbens is primarily involved in reward and sensation-seeking.)

options.label: D
options.text: Motor control (The nucleus accumbens is not primarily involved in motor control.)

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the response of the nucleus accumbens as hormone levels increase through puberty?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreases (The response of the nucleus accumbens actually increases as hormone levels increase through puberty.)

options.label: B
options.text: Remains the same (The response of the nucleus accumbens does not remain the same as hormone levels increase through puberty.)

options.label: C
options.text: Increases (The response of the nucleus accumbens increases as hormone levels increase through puberty.)

options.label: D
options.text: Fluctuates (The response of the nucleus accumbens does not fluctuate as hormone levels increase through puberty.)

multiple-choice.question: Which brain regions help impose emotional regulation and impulse control?

options.label: A
options.text: Limbic system (The limbic system is involved in emotional behavior, but not primarily in emotional regulation and impulse control.)

options.label: B
options.text: Nucleus accumbens (The nucleus accumbens is involved in reward and sensation-seeking, but not primarily in emotional regulation and impulse control.)

options.label: C
options.text: Higher cortical brain regions (Higher cortical brain regions are involved in emotional regulation and impulse control.)

options.label: D
options.text: Amygdala (The amygdala is involved in detecting threats and recognizing emotions, but not primarily in emotional regulation and impulse control.)

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the development of the adolescent brain?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more impulsive (This is a common perception, but not necessarily true.)

options.label: B
options.text: They are more rigid (This is not true, the adolescent brain is more adaptable.)

options.label: C
options.text: They are more adaptable (The adolescent brain is more adaptable than other stages of development.)

options.label: D
options.text: They are more sensitive (This is not unique to the adolescent brain.)

multiple-choice.question: What may influence the development of the brain as much as hormones during adolescence?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetics (Genetics play a role, but are not the only factor.)

options.label: B
options.text: Experiences (Experiences play a significant role in the development of the brain during adolescence.)

options.label: C
options.text: Environment (The environment plays a role, but is not the only factor.)

options.label: D
options.text: Diet (Diet is not a significant factor in the development of the brain during adolescence.)

multiple-choice.question: What do everyday choices made during adolescence have the power to shape?

options.label: A
options.text: The physical body (Everyday choices do not have a direct impact on the physical body during adolescence.)

options.label: B
options.text: The emotional behavior (Everyday choices can impact emotional behavior, but not directly shape the developing brain.)

options.label: C
options.text: The developing brain and the path of who you are and will become (Everyday choices have the power to shape the developing brain and the path of who you are and will become.)

options.label: D
options.text: The social environment (Everyday choices can impact the social environment, but not directly shape the developing brain.)

title: You don't actually know what your future self wants - Shankar Vendantam

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that the speaker is trying to convey in this talk?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of staying true to oneself.

options.label: B
options.text: The illusion of continuity and how it affects our lives.

options.label: C
options.text: The benefits of human behavior and how to apply psychological science to our lives.

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of technology on human behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's reason for not telling his parents about his injured foot when he was 12 years old?

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the paradox of looking backwards versus looking forwards?

options.label: A
options.text: We tend to imagine that we'll stay the same when we look backwards, but we can see how we've changed when we look forwards.

options.label: B
options.text: We tend to imagine that we'll change more when we look forwards, but we can see how we've changed when we look backwards.

options.label: C
options.text: We tend to imagine that we'll change less when we look forwards, but we can see how we've changed when we look backwards.

options.label: D
options.text: We tend to imagine that we'll stay the same when we look forwards, but we can see how we've changed when we look backwards.

options.label: A

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: We might not be able to change our minds.

options.label: C

title: Is it possible to lose weight fast? - Hei Man Chan

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the bizarre diet in Victorian England that involved swallowing an unhatched tapeworm and letting it grow inside the dieter's body?

options.label: A
options.text: Extreme Calorie Reduction Diet

options.label: B
options.text: Detoxification Diet

options.label: C
options.text: Starvation Diet

options.label: D
options.text: Tapeworm Diet

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's body when they create an energy deficit by decreasing calorie intake and increasing regular exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: The body stores energy as glycogen

options.label: B
options.text: The body breaks down muscle mass

options.label: C
options.text: The body starts breaking down emergency glucose in the liver

options.label: D
options.text: The body starts burning fat cells as a major energy source

options.label: C
options.text: Sam's diet includes regular exercise, while Felix's diet does not

options.label: D
options.text: Sam's diet is vegetarian, while Felix's diet is not

options.label: A
options.text: The body starts burning fat cells as a major energy source

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: There is no recommended rate of weight loss

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A juice diet is too specific and can be disastrous for someone high in vitamin A

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive

options.label: B
options.text: They are too time-consuming

options.label: C
options.text: They can have negative side effects, are not sustainable, and can compromise the immune system

options.label: D
options.text: They are not effective

options.label: D

title: The original ring of power - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: In Plato's "Republic," what is the main argument that Glaucon presents against Socrates?

options.label: A
options.text: Glaucon argues that justice is a means to an end, but not an end in itself.

options.label: B
options.text: Glaucon argues that people act justly because it's what's right, not because of external influences.

options.label: C
options.text: Glaucon argues that people act justly because it's a convention enforced through punishment and reward.

options.label: D
options.text: Glaucon argues that people act justly because it's a natural inclination.

multiple-choice.question: According to Glaucon, what are the three classes of good things that people desire?

options.label: A
options.text: Pleasure, knowledge, and wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: Harmless pleasure, exercise, and medicine.

options.label: C
options.text: Experience, value, and knowledge.

options.label: D
options.text: Good things, onerous things, and things that bring value.

multiple-choice.question: In the context of the Ring of Gyges, what does Socrates mean by saying that the tyrant succumbs to appetite and acts unjustly?

options.label: A
options.text: The tyrant is driven by a desire for power and wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: The tyrant is driven by a desire for knowledge and wisdom.

options.label: C
options.text: The tyrant is driven by a desire for pleasure and luxury.

options.label: D
options.text: The tyrant is driven by a desire for immediate gratification and is unable to check their own baser desires.

multiple-choice.question: According to Socrates, what is the relationship between reason, spirit, and appetite in the human soul?

options.label: A
options.text: Reason guides an individual to truth and is influenced by either spirit or appetite.

options.label: B
options.text: Spirit is influenced by appetite, and reason is influenced by spirit.

options.label: C
options.text: Appetite guides an individual to truth and knowledge, and is influenced by reason.

options.label: D
options.text: Reason is influenced by spirit, and appetite is influenced by reason.

multiple-choice.question: Who is the Chinese philosopher that similarly reasoned that by simply acting justly, one also benefits oneself?

options.label: A
options.text: Confucius

options.label: B
options.text: Lao Tzu

options.label: C
options.text: Mencius

options.label: D
options.text: Xunzi

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument of Thomas Hobbes regarding the state of nature and justice?

options.label: A
options.text: People are naturally obligated to act justly and they agree to participate in civil society to secure their natural rights.

options.label: B
options.text: The state of nature is violent and selfish, and justice is imposed by authority.

options.label: C
options.text: People are naturally just and only act unjustly when they are influenced by external factors.

options.label: D
options.text: The state of nature is peaceful and just, and people only act unjustly when they are influenced by external factors.

multiple-choice.question: According to John Locke, what is the reason why people agree to participate in civil society?

options.label: A
options.text: To impose justice on others.

options.label: B
options.text: To benefit themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: To act justly.

options.label: D
options.text: To secure their natural rights.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the allegory of the Ring of Gyges in the context of the discussion on justice?

options.label: A
options.text: It illustrates the importance of acting justly for its own sake.

options.label: B
options.text: It illustrates the idea that people act justly because it's what's right.

options.label: C
options.text: It illustrates the idea that people act justly because it's a means to an end.

options.label: D
options.text: It illustrates the idea that people act unjustly because it's a means to gain power and wealth.

multiple-choice.question: If the Ring of Gyges fell into your hands, what would you do according to Socrates?

options.label: A
options.text: You would use it to gain power and wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: You would act justly virtuously, and be guided by reason.

options.label: C
options.text: You would use it to benefit yourself.

options.label: D
options.text: You would use it to impose justice on others.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the questions that the reader should ask themselves before considering joining the gig economy?

options.text: How much do I value knowing exactly what I'll earn from week to week?
